"The magic of Rampal seems to be unique. In his
hands the flute is three or four music makers; his
virtuosity simply cannot be indicated in words, and
Mr. Veyron-Lacroix is, in every respect, a worthy
partner."
Born in Marseille, Rampal is considered by many
as the world's greatest living exponent of the flute.
He had completed with high distinction more than
three-quarters of the work leading to a medical degree before he was pravailed upon to enroll in the
Conservatoire Nationale de Musique de Paris. There,
after five short months in the classes of Gaston
Crunelle, Rampal was awarded First Prize in Flute.
Since the outset of his career, Rampal has toured
throughout Western Europe many times, and also in
Africa, the Far East, the United States, and Canada.
He has appeared with the great orchestras of many
with France's Lamoureux
lands, most often
Orchestre. He has also played at most of the leading
music festivals in Europe and, at various times during
his career, has recorded no fewer than fifteen dif-

ferent labels. Many distinguished composers, such as
Andre Jolivet, Jean Rivier, and Jean-Michel Damase,
have dedicated works to Mr. Rampal, which he has
premiered.
Robert Veyron-Lacroix is known as one of the
finest keyboard artists of the present day. The depth,
delicacy, and precision of his playing has made his
name famous in Western Europe, as well as throughout the rest of the world.
Like his companion, Veyron-Lacroix studied at the
Conservatoire National de Musique. He was awarded
an almost unprecedented number of the Conservatoire's First Prizes: First Prize in Piano, in Harmony. in Counterpoint, in Accompaniment, and in
Sofeggio.
Veyron-Lacroix has, several times, been an invited
soloist at the Prague Festival and has made other
festival appearances at. Aix-en-Provence, Menton,
Besancon, and Granada, to mention a few. When not
on tour, he is Professor of Harpsichord at the Schola
Cantorum in Paris.

How significant is the liberal point of view? 18 it a
representative anti intellectually inspired seetor of public opinion or are its members, as many students on the
Hopkins are given to believe, players of "juvenile antics"
and "in no way reflecting the thoughts of the sober
American College Student?"
In effect, the liberal opinionated may very well be
in small numbers compared to the mass of local or
national citizenry, but the question is raised: is not the
large measure of the population limited in its grasp of
contemporar3, issues?
The contention that a small group of the population has made a bigger noise than their corporate
strength or rightness deserves and thus made a distortion
of the public opinion make-up, especially in Universities
is a common one, but untrue, It is apparent in campus
presentations, forums, constant discussion and analysis
of political opinion, that the liberals hold the fore.
And though the relative parade-attendance figures in
New York show the rightists to have a higher number
of marchers, the voice above the crowd has constantly
been the liberal.
If measured in a count limited to those who have
resolutely informed themsehes on the war in Viet Nam,
the liberals would by no means find themselves the
minority.
It is by virtue of this capacity for intellectual involvement and imaginative presentation that the liberal
group, apparently in the minority, has received the press
and thereby greater public recognition. In effect the
power and persuasion of the left is no public illusion,
but a fact based on individual endeavor.
We can not, with absolute good conscience, support
the left as the conscience of our country; we are often
concerned that the local group is cluttered with neuroses,
are guilty of too grand designs and give way to colorful
exhibition before sensible exposition; and while we
choose not to endorse the extreme tactical opposition
of administrative policy, we have shown, and will continue to show, by way of attention, an endorsement of
the enlightenment and the relative value of the "New
Left."

We have all read that a prime
Johnson administration goal is
to get intellectual support for his
position in Viet Nam. The appearance of Dean Rusk on our
campus is said to confirm this
policy. The Republican position
on Viet Nam, as probably best
expressed by former Vice-President Nixon, has been criticized
by a New York Times editorial
of October 11, 1965 as being a
gross simplification of an immensely complex problem.
I am willing to grant the fact
that there are stupendous political and diplomatic stumbling

blocks to a solution. However,
I refuse to believe that the intellectual and practical approach
differ. The problem is not new.
It has been warmed over hundreds of times in history, political science, and philosophy
courses at this university.
The issue in Viet Nam is how
much freedom the people must
forfeit in exchange for a peaceful government. The record in
Viet Nam since 1954 shows a willingness and a desire to try
something other than a dictatorship which would deprive all
freedom. In 1176, the U.S. made
a commitment to John Locke's
inalienable rights: life, liberty,

property, and the pursuit of happiness. The Declaration said all
men were entitled to these rights.
It did not say all men had to
accept them. All Communist regimes have taken away these
rights, often by force. The policy
of the U.S. has not been to fight
for these rights after they have
been surrendered. War has been
waged only when established
rights have been threatened by a
suppressive outside force. Totalitarian aggression anywhere in
the world has always been treated by Americans as a direct attack on our natural rights beliefs.

Wars are not fought for selfish gains. My ancestors did not
fight in World War II to preserve their homes, because they
and their homes were destroyed
in many cases. The fought to
protect my future home and succeeded. The same is true of a
labor war. Men on strike never
make back their lost wages. The
benefits of the strike go to the
new workers. The benefits of all
wars go to the succeeding generations if there are any.
War is the lowest form of
existence. The anguished screams
coming from soldiers in the Viet
Jungle cannot be distinguished
on the basis of race, religion or
language. Pain and suffering are
universally understood. Republicans stand with President Johnson on this issue not because of
its advantages, but because of
the lack of acceptable alternatives.

CINEMA

Climbing 'The Hill' In Borrowed Boots
Sidney Lumet has never made
a film of his own, but presumably he is learning something by
copying the works of other film
makers.
In 1940 Orson Welles learned
how to make Citizen Caine by
studying John Ford's Stagecoach the saw the film forty
times). Stanley Kubrick learnid
film making by watching the
films in the Museum of Modern
Arts collection over a two year
period. It is apparent that this
method of study is an excellent
way to learn film making.
Despite the high .cost of films
today there is a smal group
of film makers who learn about
film making by making films.
Most notable in this group is
Roger Carman who has made
about fifty films in the past ten
years and is just now being realized as a competent film maker.
Sidney Lumet is another one,

of these film makers who makes
films as a method of study. Unlike the French directors who allude to the style of other directors as a tribute, Lumet merely
lifts the technique and style of
other directors and pawns it off
as his own. The elements of
other directors styles are always
present in Lumet's films. In the
Pawnbroker he tried some of
Alain Resnais' (Night and Fog,
Last Year at Marienbad) techniques and now in The Hill Lumet tries Kubrick and others. It
remains to be seen if this method
of film making is good training.
Lumet's method of film making is not entirely dishonest, because, despite his employment of
formulas that seem to succeed

financially, he is constantly experimenting within these frameworks. In some cases it is beginning to be apparent that he is
developing his own style—particularly in his use of sound
montage, (the end of Failsafe
and The Hill), and his photographic techniques. Lumet makes
many mistakes, but in many
cfses it is because he purposely
chooses difficult material which
someday he may be capable of
handling.

Parts of the film are inexplicable because some of the characters are not properly identified in
particular scenes.

The Hill. Lumet's latest film,
now at the Playhouse, is about
a military prison of the British
army during the Second World
War. Actually as it turns out the
prison is merely a convenient

Sean Connery puts on a remarkable performance and certainly demonstrates that he is
a much more serious actor than
the James Bond films might indicate.

element, a microcosm of the
army and humanity in general.
At first the film appears to be a
documented study of sadism but
gradually other elements are
brought into consideration. Unfortunately the quality of the
sound is rather poor and this in
combination with the heavy
British accents it is possible to
miss much of the dialogue.

The most apparent reason for
the failure of the film is the
obviousness of the elements in
the film .. . the Negro, the
drunk the fatman the homosexual, and the in.subordinant
criminal hero.
Desipte all the failings the
film is worth seeing for the experimentation in editing, (Lumet
breaks the rules by cutting from
shots of heads composed on the
left of the screen to shots composed on the right of the screen)
the use of hand held camera
shots, and of course the acting
on the part of Sean Connery.
Unlike Stanley Kubrick's Paths
of Glory, The Hill ends on a
rather pessimistic note.

Frosh Footballers Frosh Booters
Showing Strength To Test Navy
By TONY STONE
The freshman football team,
which showed strength in both
offense and defense in a decisive
win over Western Maryland Jayvee, visits Penn Military College
today.
Hopkins scored in the first
quarter against Western Maryland after Willie Scroggs climaxed a sixty-yard drive with
a three yard run for the score.
Two points were added as Jim
Feely passed to John Cardillo.
T,he second touchdown came
in the second half on a two
yard run by Mark Croft. The
two point pass play was incom-

Souring Gridders
Season Spoilers
(Continued from Page 10)
mentor, "was a play near the
end of the first half. Bob Shannon just missed an interception
with a clear field ahead of him,
so we lost a chance to go in at
halftime only one touchdown
down, which could have put a
different complexion on things
In the third quarter."
Western Maryland, whom the
Jays host on November 20, was
4-2 overall and 0-1 in MasonDixon Conference play as of last
week. The Terrors ranked fifth in
conference standings, behind
Hampden-Sydney, Shepard,
Randolph-Macon, and Bridgewater.

Coach Chuck Mallonee's freshman soccer team visits the Navy
Plebes Wednesday needing a
victory to wind up the season
3-0-1.
The booters so far have beaten
Calvert Hall College and Gettysburg while tying Franklin and
Marshall, Scores were 7-1, 3-1.
and 2-2, respectively.

plete, and the frosh led at the
half 14-0.
Early in the fourth period,
Hopkins picked up eight more
points on two passes by Jim
Feely. The six pointer was an
eight-yard pass play to John
Cardillo, and the extra points
play was to Gorczyk. The Terrors scored in the remaining
minutes of the period.
Passing Effective
The total offense was much
stronger than in the previous
game with Franklin and Marshall. The running attack totaled
209 yards, with Mark Croft
picking up 100 yards in seventeen
carries and Willie Scroggs rushing 95 yards in sixteen attempts.
Scroggs (co-captain for the
game) had previously confined
his abilities to defense, carrying
the ball only once in the F&M
game.
Feely quarterbacked most of
the game and completed twelve
of sixteen passes for 138 yards.
John Gorczyk caught five for 90
yards, and Cardillo handled six
for 45 yards.
The defensive unit led by cocaptain John Beck did an excellent job in holding Western
Maryland to a total offense of
111 yards.

Mallonee's lineup has Walter
Warnick, John Marshall, and
Tom Hess at fullback; Jeff Lobel
and Barfly Usler on the line; and
Greg Sarau, Roger Perdiun, Phil
Lampkau, Dave Rockwell, and
Phil Moss as halfbacks.
Wings are Bill Gonzales and
Ken Niman, with Lou Sardello
right inside and Art Guerin left
inside. Bill Ellis - and Tom
Ahrendt are also listed on the
line. Mike Avery is goalie.
"Our weak point has been our
fullbacks," cited Mallonee, "but
Marshall can kick the ball a
mile, Hess plays position, and
Warnick has plenty of aggressiveness. Put them all together
and you've got one pretty good
ballplayer.
"Avery", he went on, "came
up with six or seven sensational
saves against F&M, some like
I've never seen before."

At many companies the opportunity to work on
challenging projects comes after many years of
apprenticeship and a few grey hairs. Not so at
Ford Motor Company where your twenties can
be a stimulating period. There are opportunities
to prove your worth early in your career. Dale
Anderson's experience is a case in point.
After receiving his B.A. in Physics in June, "1962;
Dale joined our College Graduate Program and
was assigned to our Research Laboratories.
Recently he was given the responsibility for °orflue Anderson
recting cab vibration occurring on a particular
B.A., Wittentwg Uniwrsity
type of truck. His studies showed that tire eccentricity was the cause of the trouble. Since little change could be effected
in tire compliance, his solution lay in redesigning the suspension system.
Tests of this experimental system show the problem to be reduced to an
insignificant level.
That's typical of the kind of meaningful assignments given to employes
while still in the College Graduate Program—regardless of their career
interest. No "make work" superficial jobs. And, besides offering the opportunity to work on important problems demanding fresh solutions, we offer
good salaries, a highly professional atmosphere and the proximity to ,
leading universities.

"The magic of Rampal seems to be unique. In his
hands the flute is three or four music makers; his
virtuosity simply cannot be indicated in words, and
Mr. Veyron-Lacroix is, in every respect, a worthy
partner."
Born in Marseille, Rampal is considered by many
as the world's greatest living exponent of the flute.
He had completed with high distinction more than
three-quarters of the work leading to a medical degree before he was pravailed upon to enroll in the
Conservatoire Nationale de Musique de Paris. There,
after five short months in the classes of Gaston
Crunelle, Rampal was awarded First Prize in Flute.
Since the outset of his career, Rampal has toured
throughout Western Europe many times, and also in
Africa, the Far East, the United States, and Canada.
He has appeared with the great orchestras of many
with France's Lamoureux
lands, most often
Orchestre. He has also played at most of the leading
music festivals in Europe and, at various times during
his career, has recorded no fewer than fifteen dif-

ferent labels. Many distinguished composers, such as
Andre Jolivet, Jean Rivier, and Jean-Michel Damase,
have dedicated works to Mr. Rampal, which he has
premiered.
Robert Veyron-Lacroix is known as one of the
finest keyboard artists of the present day. The depth,
delicacy, and precision of his playing has made his
name famous in Western Europe, as well as throughout the rest of the world.
Like his companion, Veyron-Lacroix studied at the
Conservatoire National de Musique. He was awarded
an almost unprecedented number of the Conservatoire's First Prizes: First Prize in Piano, in Harmony. in Counterpoint, in Accompaniment, and in
Sofeggio.
Veyron-Lacroix has, several times, been an invited
soloist at the Prague Festival and has made other
festival appearances at. Aix-en-Provence, Menton,
Besancon, and Granada, to mention a few. When not
on tour, he is Professor of Harpsichord at the Schola
Cantorum in Paris.

How significant is the liberal point of view? 18 it a
representative anti intellectually inspired seetor of public opinion or are its members, as many students on the
Hopkins are given to believe, players of "juvenile antics"
and "in no way reflecting the thoughts of the sober
American College Student?"
In effect, the liberal opinionated may very well be
in small numbers compared to the mass of local or
national citizenry, but the question is raised: is not the
large measure of the population limited in its grasp of
contemporar3, issues?
The contention that a small group of the population has made a bigger noise than their corporate
strength or rightness deserves and thus made a distortion
of the public opinion make-up, especially in Universities
is a common one, but untrue, It is apparent in campus
presentations, forums, constant discussion and analysis
of political opinion, that the liberals hold the fore.
And though the relative parade-attendance figures in
New York show the rightists to have a higher number
of marchers, the voice above the crowd has constantly
been the liberal.
If measured in a count limited to those who have
resolutely informed themsehes on the war in Viet Nam,
the liberals would by no means find themselves the
minority.
It is by virtue of this capacity for intellectual involvement and imaginative presentation that the liberal
group, apparently in the minority, has received the press
and thereby greater public recognition. In effect the
power and persuasion of the left is no public illusion,
but a fact based on individual endeavor.
We can not, with absolute good conscience, support
the left as the conscience of our country; we are often
concerned that the local group is cluttered with neuroses,
are guilty of too grand designs and give way to colorful
exhibition before sensible exposition; and while we
choose not to endorse the extreme tactical opposition
of administrative policy, we have shown, and will continue to show, by way of attention, an endorsement of
the enlightenment and the relative value of the "New
Left."

We have all read that a prime
Johnson administration goal is
to get intellectual support for his
position in Viet Nam. The appearance of Dean Rusk on our
campus is said to confirm this
policy. The Republican position
on Viet Nam, as probably best
expressed by former Vice-President Nixon, has been criticized
by a New York Times editorial
of October 11, 1965 as being a
gross simplification of an immensely complex problem.
I am willing to grant the fact
that there are stupendous political and diplomatic stumbling

blocks to a solution. However,
I refuse to believe that the intellectual and practical approach
differ. The problem is not new.
It has been warmed over hundreds of times in history, political science, and philosophy
courses at this university.
The issue in Viet Nam is how
much freedom the people must
forfeit in exchange for a peaceful government. The record in
Viet Nam since 1954 shows a willingness and a desire to try
something other than a dictatorship which would deprive all
freedom. In 1176, the U.S. made
a commitment to John Locke's
inalienable rights: life, liberty,

property, and the pursuit of happiness. The Declaration said all
men were entitled to these rights.
It did not say all men had to
accept them. All Communist regimes have taken away these
rights, often by force. The policy
of the U.S. has not been to fight
for these rights after they have
been surrendered. War has been
waged only when established
rights have been threatened by a
suppressive outside force. Totalitarian aggression anywhere in
the world has always been treated by Americans as a direct attack on our natural rights beliefs.

Wars are not fought for selfish gains. My ancestors did not
fight in World War II to preserve their homes, because they
and their homes were destroyed
in many cases. The fought to
protect my future home and succeeded. The same is true of a
labor war. Men on strike never
make back their lost wages. The
benefits of the strike go to the
new workers. The benefits of all
wars go to the succeeding generations if there are any.
War is the lowest form of
existence. The anguished screams
coming from soldiers in the Viet
Jungle cannot be distinguished
on the basis of race, religion or
language. Pain and suffering are
universally understood. Republicans stand with President Johnson on this issue not because of
its advantages, but because of
the lack of acceptable alternatives.

CINEMA

Climbing 'The Hill' In Borrowed Boots
Sidney Lumet has never made
a film of his own, but presumably he is learning something by
copying the works of other film
makers.
In 1940 Orson Welles learned
how to make Citizen Caine by
studying John Ford's Stagecoach the saw the film forty
times). Stanley Kubrick learnid
film making by watching the
films in the Museum of Modern
Arts collection over a two year
period. It is apparent that this
method of study is an excellent
way to learn film making.
Despite the high .cost of films
today there is a smal group
of film makers who learn about
film making by making films.
Most notable in this group is
Roger Carman who has made
about fifty films in the past ten
years and is just now being realized as a competent film maker.
Sidney Lumet is another one,

of these film makers who makes
films as a method of study. Unlike the French directors who allude to the style of other directors as a tribute, Lumet merely
lifts the technique and style of
other directors and pawns it off
as his own. The elements of
other directors styles are always
present in Lumet's films. In the
Pawnbroker he tried some of
Alain Resnais' (Night and Fog,
Last Year at Marienbad) techniques and now in The Hill Lumet tries Kubrick and others. It
remains to be seen if this method
of film making is good training.
Lumet's method of film making is not entirely dishonest, because, despite his employment of
formulas that seem to succeed

financially, he is constantly experimenting within these frameworks. In some cases it is beginning to be apparent that he is
developing his own style—particularly in his use of sound
montage, (the end of Failsafe
and The Hill), and his photographic techniques. Lumet makes
many mistakes, but in many
cfses it is because he purposely
chooses difficult material which
someday he may be capable of
handling.

Parts of the film are inexplicable because some of the characters are not properly identified in
particular scenes.

The Hill. Lumet's latest film,
now at the Playhouse, is about
a military prison of the British
army during the Second World
War. Actually as it turns out the
prison is merely a convenient

Sean Connery puts on a remarkable performance and certainly demonstrates that he is
a much more serious actor than
the James Bond films might indicate.

element, a microcosm of the
army and humanity in general.
At first the film appears to be a
documented study of sadism but
gradually other elements are
brought into consideration. Unfortunately the quality of the
sound is rather poor and this in
combination with the heavy
British accents it is possible to
miss much of the dialogue.

The most apparent reason for
the failure of the film is the
obviousness of the elements in
the film .. . the Negro, the
drunk the fatman the homosexual, and the in.subordinant
criminal hero.
Desipte all the failings the
film is worth seeing for the experimentation in editing, (Lumet
breaks the rules by cutting from
shots of heads composed on the
left of the screen to shots composed on the right of the screen)
the use of hand held camera
shots, and of course the acting
on the part of Sean Connery.
Unlike Stanley Kubrick's Paths
of Glory, The Hill ends on a
rather pessimistic note.

picking up 100 yards in seventeen
carries and Willie Scroggs rushing 95 yards in sixteen attempts.
Scroggs (co-captain for the
game) had previously confined
his abilities to defense, carrying
the ball only once in the F&M
game.
Feely quarterbacked most of
the game and completed twelve
of sixteen passes for 138 yards.
John Gorczyk caught five for 90
yards, and Cardillo handled six
for 45 yards.
The defensive unit led by cocaptain John Beck did an excellent job in holding Western
Maryland to a total offense of
111 yards.

Mallonee's lineup has Walter
Warnick, John Marshall, and
Tom Hess at fullback; Jeff Lobel
and Barfly Usler on the line; and
Greg Sarau, Roger Perdiun, Phil
Lampkau, Dave Rockwell, and
Phil Moss as halfbacks.
Wings are Bill Gonzales and
Ken Niman, with Lou Sardello
right inside and Art Guerin left
inside. Bill Ellis - and Tom
Ahrendt are also listed on the
line. Mike Avery is goalie.
"Our weak point has been our
fullbacks," cited Mallonee, "but
Marshall can kick the ball a
mile, Hess plays position, and
Warnick has plenty of aggressiveness. Put them all together
and you've got one pretty good
ballplayer.
"Avery", he went on, "came
up with six or seven sensational
saves against F&M, some like
I've never seen before."

you wear this Arrow Cum Laude.
An antique gold and brown boxed
in with burgundy. With authentic
detailing, too. Gently flared
button-down collar. Back collar
button and box pleat. Shoulder
to waist taper. "Sanforized",
of course. $5.00. Wear it and
make a statement:
it's great to be alive.

At many companies the opportunity to work on
challenging projects comes after many years of
apprenticeship and a few grey hairs. Not so at
Ford Motor Company where your twenties can
be a stimulating period. There are opportunities
to prove your worth early in your career. Dale
Anderson's experience is a case in point.
After receiving his B.A. in Physics in June, "1962;
Dale joined our College Graduate Program and
was assigned to our Research Laboratories.
Recently he was given the responsibility for °orflue Anderson
recting cab vibration occurring on a particular
B.A., Wittentwg Uniwrsity
type of truck. His studies showed that tire eccentricity was the cause of the trouble. Since little change could be effected
in tire compliance, his solution lay in redesigning the suspension system.
Tests of this experimental system show the problem to be reduced to an
insignificant level.
That's typical of the kind of meaningful assignments given to employes
while still in the College Graduate Program—regardless of their career
interest. No "make work" superficial jobs. And, besides offering the opportunity to work on important problems demanding fresh solutions, we offer
good salaries, a highly professional atmosphere and the proximity to ,
leading universities.
Discover the rewarding opportunity Ford Motor Company may have for'
you. How? Simply schedule an interview with our representative when he
visits your campus. Let your twenties be a challenging and rewarding time.
